posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Metroid Prime (NTSC release)

>Lore is completely broken, very dry and generally a waste of time to read. More boring than I remember it being at launch actually.
>Awesome TECHNOLOGY moments
>Great soundtrack
>Backtracking is completely egregious at certain points. Like how many times you have to hike through Magmoor just to reach Phendrana, or the two useful shortcuts to the Phazon Mines being hidden way the fuck at the back of the Chozo Ruins.
>Very tedious combat at times. Respawning enemies can be a chore that hinders exploration.

Overall I think I have a greater appreciation for Super now than I did previously. Prime is still worth playing but I don't think its a masterpiece.

Eternal Darkness

>Completely over rated
>Doesn't even make very good use of having to repeat the same 3 levels over and over again
>Combat is shallow and boring
>Sanity effects are still awesome and a few genuinely caught me off guard
>Dull, uninspired story that doesn't make the most of its premise
>NAROKOTH, REDGOMOR, PARGON, PARGON, PARGON, PARGON, PARGON
>Making the player repeat the final underground city section TWICE was pure madness, I couldn't believe how fucked up and boring that was.
>Too easy, even on the hardest Eldritch god, and has no resource management that makes survival horror games interesting.
>Some good atmospheric moments here and there.

Yeah, really didn't like that one.

posts.com:
Too many QoL features can ruin an experience. Balancing changes like full restores on level ups and the busted new party members in 3DS make the game too boring. Visuals and sound carry the game hard and PSCX2's latest version runs the game pretty much perfectly. (no more black squares around certain sprites for ex.) Only issue is it can be a sluggish game in general thanks to slow walk speed, text speed & some weird line delivery - not sure how much of that the 3DS version fixes.The bonus dungeons are unnecessary padding, some people might like them, I'm fine with the single bonus dungeon in the base game.

I'd say the optimal experience is emulate the PS2 version, use fast forward if you need it, and go through the trouble of hacking in the gospel ring if you really, really hate random encounters. You're missing a beautiful game if you opt for the 3DS version.

posts.sub: POV: You're Designing an Arcade Video Game in 1975
posts.com:
What I'd make:
>a really simple and accessible turn based RPG, with an simple randomized open world, randomized towns, randomized dungeon, and randomized bossfights in each dungeon for greater longevity
>inspired by "dnd" for the PLATO mainframe computer
>simple randomized towns where you can upgrade your gears and purchase healing items
>killing a boss will yield a randomized reward at the town you're visiting
>powered by intel 8080 or mororolla 6800 CPU, probably using a modified Altair 8800 or SWTPC 6800 microcomputer kits with a random number generator hardware added, and having its ASCII character display modified into character semigraphics
>programmable in BASIC for a speedy game development
>16KB of RAM, about enough to store the memory of the BASIC interpreter and the game data itself, cant be too much because RAM was expensive
>48KB of internal MROM board to store the game software and BASIC software, must have been plenty in 1975
>a slot for an EPROM board for adding new content or fixing some bugs if necessary
>noise generator like in most Atari and Midway arcade machines
>a slot for 64 byte battery backed SRAM cartridge to store game progress, this is what the players would have to buy at the arcade store before playing the game
>25 cents for a 200-turn game session, each player character step will reduce the turns the player has, if no input is made within 30 seconds, player will have to insert another quarter or the game automatically ends
>death will reduce the player's money and experience progress by 30%, but it's ultimately not very punishing, it has to be player friendly or no one would play it again
>$450 computer kit with 4K RAM + $600 12K RAM expansion + $300 terminal screen + $1000 everything else i guess= $2,350 cost per cabinet, retails for $2,800, about the price of a cheap used car in 1975
Would it sell?

I got the game for Christmas the year that it released. To this day I have never met another person who even owns a copy of the game, so needless to say I never got to experience the multiplayer.

Nightmare in Dreamland has multiplayer. If both players own the game, you can play through the levels together*. Amazing Mirror is the same except that you can also go off and explore on your own. I would love to play through this with other people.

*If only one player has the game you can do mini games together.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I don't know about Kirby, but I know for the most part it seemed like GB/GBA games didn't get played a lot in multiplayer in my area. A lot of people owned a GB and played Pokemon at first, but by Gen2 popularity was waning and then when the GBA came out, a lot of people just stuck to consoles.

That said, I knew one other guy who had a GBA and we played Golden Sun Vs, Advance Wars, and Fire Emblem against each other. Eventually when I got a Wii, I picked up FF Crystal Chronicles and me and him brought our GBAs (Each of us had a normal GBA and an SP model), I ordered the cables needed off of ebay, and me and three other friends played through CC together and had a good time, kind of the same feeling we used to get playing Gauntlet. It's kind of sad to think those games are relegated to the past and basically no one plays them anymore.

I like Seymour for what he is.
He's certainly not a good enough character to be the main antagonist, but he's a great recurring villain.
It's interesting how he's thinking and acting on an entirely different scale than every other character in the game.
I also like that you can use a turn to call him a piece of shit mid-battle. That's fucking great, every Final Fantasy game should do that.

I never felt that the characters were written too irrationally.
Auron has his own plan, Tidus doesn't know what's going on, Rikku is trying her best, and everyone else has a martyr complex the size of Arizona.
There are a few scenes that are played for melodrama but nothing was a dealbreaker for me.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9643125
>Random Encounters
I don't know why this is such a big deal to people.
Does seeing the enemy on the map and bumping into them before combat really just light your soul on fire? I've never cared that much.
If you hate them, there's a way to earn the ability to turn off random encounters in game. Is that still not enough for you?
>Bad writing
The Japanese version has very solid writing.
I haven't seen the English version in a while but from my memory it isn't particularly worse than other JRPG translations.
>Unskippable cutscenes
There are a few boss fights in this game that use Petrify and Death status effects, and unless you keep anti-stone anti-death equips on 100% of the time there's a good chance you'll have to go through them more than once.
Other than that I can't think of any situation you would want to skip a cutscene in this game.
>Save points
It's 2023. If this is a dealbreaker for you, use save states.
>Bad tutorials
By this I'm assuming you're talking about the in battle tutorials where the characters give advice to each other?
Those end in Mi'ihen and I thought they were cute. In total, they're like, two minutes of the game, max.
>Awful character design
I think Yuna, Rikku, and Lulu have awesome character designs, as do all the summons.
Auron and Kimahri look pretty cool too imo.
Tidus and Wakka are fashion rejects, but in a kind of lovable way that makes sense for their characters.
>Weird voices
I can only recommend you play the Japanese version or one of the many undubs.

>>9643384
>Other than that I can't think of any situation you would want to skip a cutscene in this game.
Not him, but I remember restarting a few times to win that first blitzball match and the unskippable intro cutscene was annoying. Besides that, why would you want to skip cutscenes in a story-driven RPG?
I don't mind it as a QoL improvement though, especially if it comes with a pause function. Some games just slap skip on the start button without telling you so, when it acts as pause everywhere else in the game and that's stupid and counter-intuitive. A perfect way to do this is to have the start button pause the cutscene and then offer you an option to skip or resume it, like in MGS4 or the Yakuza series, for example. That should really be a standard for all games. Too bad they didn't include it in the remaster.
>I can only recommend you play the Japanese version or one of the many undubs.
Seconded. I can't bear the English dub in this game, it ruins it for me. The original voices are MUCH better. Again, I wish the remaster let you change the language without resorting to mods and file-swapping (which makes it exclusive to the PC version, too).
In general, FF dubs had a rough start in English, but every installment starting from XII onwards had a great dub. Sure, there are a few exceptions like Vanille sounding outright retarded in XIII, but for most of the time they're pretty good, even if I prefer Japanese voices overall (save for XII, the EN dub is phenomenal and I prefer it over JP).
On that note, which dub is supposed to be the main one for XVI? I feel like the English voices are going to be really strong this time, but I'll probably play the game more than once and taste both anyway.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9646192
I just finished it in Japanese for the first time; I think you'll enjoy it.
There's some neat differences in the text, I'll put them in spoilers in case you'd rather see them first hand.
In Japanese Sin is called シン (Shin), which at first appears to just be how they've decided to pronounce the English word Sin, but later on in the story when it's revealed that Sin is not actually Spira's punishment, it turns out that the true meaning of his name is 死 (death).
Yu Yevon's original name is Ebon Jew, was probably changed to avoid people thinking the game was antisemitic.
All of Lulu's dialogue is completely different. The double entendre's were all added in the dub. She mostly just calls upon the spirits to help defeat her enemies. It changes the feel of her character a lot.
As you might expect, the Al Bhed dictionary sidequest is quite different. There are still 26 dictionaries, but each one gives you several kana instead of one letter.
One thing to note is that there's a lot of dialogue that advances automatically, so if you aren't confident in your comprehension speed you might want to consider playing it in an emulator so you can pause if you want.
I have a lot of Japanese experience and I still got lost a few times when the dialogue is talking about how the 幻光虫 cause the 祈り子 to give the 召喚士 their 召喚獣 and their 異界送り. Feels like fantasy technobabble.

>>9652101
Its so fucking weird because it sets up a bunch of big moments later. For example: Yuna tells Tidus to force a laughter when he's sad. Because that's what Yuna does. Because Yuna knows she's doomed and dwelling on it will make the pilgrimage harder. So she makes herself smile and laugh even when she's feeling miserable or hopeless. Which should make you retroactively look at that scene with a sad lens. But in Macalania before the kiss Tidus gives Yuna an out. That she can run away with him to live their lives. And for the only time in the game Yuna muses on what life like that would be like before breaking down in tears and admiting she can't have the life she actually wants. Sin is a plague. She can kill it. But that means she has no future. And no amount of fake laughing will fix that.

But it also sets up another scene because in Bevelle, just before the end of the game this dialogue happens.

>Bahamut: But, you know… When it is all over…we will wake, and our dream will end. Our dream will vanish.
>Tidus: Yeah. You’ve been dreaming a long time, haven’t you?
>Bahamut: I’m sorry.
>Tidus: I’m grateful.
>Bahamut: (Vanishes)
>Yuna: About what?
>Tidus: Oh, nothing. Hey, don’t make that face! Come on! We’re going to beat Sin! Let’s see some cheer, okay?
>Yuna: You’re hiding something.
>Tidus: I’m not!
>Yuna: Really? ...You’re a bad liar, you know?

Tidus can't lie. He can't manufacture a fake laugh and he can't trick Yuna into thinking everything is fine with it isn't. Tidus is a genuine person. He wears everything on his sleeve and that laughing scene sets up how both characters function.

So you get people like >>9650341 who'll meme and say CRINGE but then when you point out the purpose of the scene and how much it sets up they'll just say YEAH BUT I DIDN'T LIKE IT. Disney tier characterization and they miss it.

>This is false, why do people keep saying that

The Sega Saturn had 1046 games:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Sega_Saturn_games

https://segaretro.org/Saturn_Backup_Memory#Compatibility

>>9640526
>Action Replay / Gameshark cannot do this. It can only back-up memory.

Also this. The older 2/3/4-in-1 cards from the 90s had additional storage, but you could only move/copy saves to them from their own Action Replay-like menu, when a game was booted they just functioned like a 4MB RAM expansion, not as a memory card. The more recent ones you get today can function as a real memory card... for those 82 games.

>>9647685
The Saturn is a great console to get if you like arcade perfect (or close to) 90s fighting games, shoot 'em ups, arcade style racing games, weird but excellent JRPGs, interesting versions of games better known on the PS1, and quirky arcade deep cuts. If that sounds good than you'll have a good time, but don't get one expecting it to be a PS1 but kinda different.

The internal differences between hardware revisions is negligible. Japanese Saturns are generally in better shape than US ones, and the gray (model 1) or white (model 2) colors look really nice. They're also significantly cheaper.

Get a Japanese Saturn imported, find a cartridge with PseudoSaturn Kai firmware on it, and you'll be able to play pirated copies of games you have burned to CD. Accessories to consider are a save cartridge (if your PSK cart doesn't have direct saving), a 3D controller (a Saturn controller with an analog stick), and an arcade stick if you're into fighting games or shooters. The PSK cart you get should have 1MB and 4MB RAM support, so you don't have to get a dedicated RAM cart (RAM carts are extra memory that is required for some games, similar to an Expansion Pack for the N64 only not as faggy). Most of the games that utilized the RAM carts were Capcom 2D fighters, but there were some others (the port of Metal Slug uses the 1MB cart, for example).

Check the /vr/ wiki for recommended games, or post what genres you're into and we can recommend some.

gl;hf and don't forget to bully the bernieposter about the time he complained on /adv/ about his wife refusing to have sex with him but forgot to turn off his tripcode whenever you see him post.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9642623
>Many popular exclusives like NiGHTS, Astal, Burning Rangers, Bulk Slash, Clockwork Knight, Scud, and all of the Panzer Dragoon games did not support the feature.

The only two games in that list that save and don't support it directly are Bulk Slash and Panzer Dragoon II. All the others that save support it. Clockwork Knight, Panzer Dragoon, Astal, etc. don't have any saving at all. So it's kind of silly to expect them to support it. NiGHTS, Burning Rangers, Panzer Dragoon Saga, etc. do support it, as do just about every single major game where saving is important. Heck some like Panzer Dragoon Saga and Madden 97 even support directly saving to the Floppy Disk Drive. For the few that only allow saving to Internal RAM you can just go into the Memory Manager and copy them over to the Cartridge or even the Floppy Drive if you are worried about the battery.

Honestly the most infuriating thing about the Saturn is the amount of misinformation that's spread around about it by people who have never even bothered to try it's games out in an emulator, let alone actually own one. And sites like Sega Retro don't help that situation at all as they're full of misinformation made by the same kind of people.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9646117
My dad worked for a law firm that used Macs (it was a holdout from the 1980s when the Mac WYSIWYG was actually quite useful for legal documents), in late 1994 they bought him a Quadra 630 so that he could work from home. I was barely 5 at the time. As >>9653132 mentioned, you didn't "have" a computer, it was usually because your parents needed one for work, or they were just nerds. I did get my parents' old computers passed down to me so they technically became "mine", but tech moved so fast in those days that, realistically, you continued to use the "new" computer that your parents owned, even if there was a "kids computer" available. I didn't get my first new PC for my own exclusive use until 2006, and that was mainly because I wanted to play Civilization IV.

NTA but do you have any recommendations from personal experience? Because everybody cares about and documents the converters the other way around, but never the HDMI *to* composite ones.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9641885
I have been milling about looking at various converters, the only good ones tend be from smaller hobbyist shops that are annoying to acquire easily.

Say you serious and are building a media PC dedicated for a CRT i think the best way to go about it is start with an older AMD GPU(15 bucks on ebay) that has DVI-I or VGA outputs then to converter then to your TV. The reason to use an older AMD GPU is because theres a driver on windows that will do resolution switching between 240p and 480i modes and all sorts of various CRT related settings that makes things work more authentically. This is an almost essential feature when dealing with an an older retro emulator machine because sprites start looking blurry without the proper 240p scanlines

HDMI does not play nicely with CRT from various CRT groups ive read, i think its because theres a floor of how low of a resolution HDMI can go down to which fucks with pixel scaling or some shit. Its just something to avoid whenever possible.

>How does Arcade games on a CRT work?
Perfectly fine.
> is there any limitations on what you can do on a consumer CRT in terms of arcade resolutions?
If it is a 24hz or 31khz arcade game then you will need a CRT that supports those resolutions. Something like a multisync monitor from NEC or Mitsubishi. 31hz is widely supported on basically any PC CRT monitor since it is similar to 640x480 vga.
>Can you even rotate consumer CRTs to play TATE without damaging them?
Yes, no problems.

>>9647927
n64 only outputs s-video at the highest, so if you want that, then sure, get something with s-video in. you could also rgb mod the n64 or use a clone console or a mister or something to get rgb output (any cable that plugs into the back of the back of the n64 is working with s-video to start out with, even if it outputs rgb). if you do get rgb output, then you can (probably) rgb mod the tv you have already. you might even be able to s-video mod it since it has the vcr. not sure, i only took a cursory look at the service manual. pvms (sony or otherwise) sometimes have rgb in, but not always. usually at least s-video (y/c) though. pvms do have a sharper picture than consumer sets, and that might make a difference sometimes, but anything over 600 TVL won't make a difference if i'm doing my math right based on the n64's 773.5 dots per line. that's probably higher than your tv, i don't see it listed in the specs. it doesn't matter that much anyway. the biggest factor is the input. composite to s-video is the biggest jump in quality from personal experience. no matter what input you use though, the fact is that the n64 only outputs 240p. things like a framemeister can upscale the video signal but upscaling can't add detail, only diminish it. if you really want to be able to see things better, then emulate and render at a higher resolution.

That's so cool. Those don't have any kind of video inputs and only tune into to channels broadcast over the air, unfortunately those are no longer broadcast since the switch to DTT (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Digital_terrestrial_television) so it won't pick up anything. If you have a NES or SNES and an RF cable you could try to hook it up to both VHF leads at the back (even barely touching should transmit a signal), put the NES/SNES switch on channel 3 and then tune on the TV knob into 3.

You turn the TV on by turning and increasing the volume like on old radio sets.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9647503
Total hyperzoomer opinion. In the 90s-2000s, you shipped a final game, and if it lived up to the sales expectations, the expansion pack you were already doing prelim work on didn’t get canceled. In the before times, if you shipped a game with a bug, you had to risk destroying your reputation and also incur huge costs by mailing out a fix to everyone who bought a copy. When the internet penetrated enough of the market, devs realized they could just put patches online for people to download—it was low cost and still an honest thing to do. It wasn’t until the late 2000s when (((developers))) and (((publishers))) figured out you could use digital distribution to ship broken/incomplete games, charge people $80 upfront, and then make them sit through “day 1” updates to play games for which they’d already paid. And then from there it was literally just a sleazy hop and jump to realize you could charge people $80 for half a game and sell the other half in 2 parts for $20 each, many months later. Add addictive grugbrain gambling on top of that and you arrive at AAA gaming in 2023. Give me CDs and shareware any day…

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9647503
Bugfixes were frequently done separately from expansions, in fact often being available without the expansions.
Expansions also were not all EA style "let's cut a piece out of the finished game and then sell it later", in fact I'm unaware of any examples from the day. That said, that's not all DLC ever made either.

Expansion packs may or may not be planned ahead, or based around "This was an idea we thought about implementing, but there wasn't the time to realize it, or we needed to retool it to work." but there's nothing shady about revisiting an unrealized idea or even finishing or retooling something cut during the game's development.

>>9647591
Often the case, also. Games which bombed didn't tend to get expansions. I think there's a few cases, but not very many.
In fact, games which continued to do well and had well received expansions could get additional new expansions.

>>9648398
You seem to have misinterpreted his statement as "All expansion packs were always good." which he really wasn't saying.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9649897
Not sure about majority, it definitely varied.

>SC Broodwar
>AoE2: Age Of Conquerors
>Wolf3D : Nocturnal Missions
>Wolf3D : Spear Of Destiny
>DN3D : Atomic Edition
>Ultimate Doom
>Doom 3 : Resurrection Of Evil
>Extreme Rise Of The Triad
These were done in-house by the same devs.
Something like Ultimate Doom is like a quasi-expansion, the intent being that since Doom 2 was going to be a retail product instead of a mail-order one like the first game, if you were buying Doom 2, you could also grab the first one and get the full experience in one go, and there was a new episode of levels to give it more of a point. If you already had the mail order version you could get it upgraded to the retail version for free.

>HL : Opposing Force
>HL : Blue Shift
>Diablo Hellfire
>Wolf3D : Spear Of Destiny Pt. 2
>Wolf3D : Spear Of Destiny Pt. 3
>Quake : Dissolution Of Eternity
>Quake : Scourge Of Armagon
>Final Doom
>Master Levels Of Doom
>DN3D : Nuclear Winter
>DN3D : Duke It Out In D.C
>Duke Caribbean : Life's A Beach
These are ones developed by other devs in part or in full. For the Duke ones, NW is trash, D.C is ok, and Caribbean is excellent, all three were made by the same team at Sunstorm as I get, possibly with the exception of a level designer.
The Spear Of Destiny sequels are trash garbage, and FormGen did some stuff which iD didn't know at first, being forced to change it. Master Levels were like a crude handpick from submissions opened for the purpose (included Maximum Doom, a shovelware disc very much like the Wizard Works ones), while Final Doom was 50% a fan level pack which iD bought the rights to, and 50% two disgruntled brothers who worked on it making a chance offer to iD.
Hellfire, famously, were a third party making an offer to Blizzard, which the devs of Diablo largely REALLY didn't want, but didn't really get any say in. It's made in part from leftover dev assets already in the retail game's files, which were much nicer than Synergistic's own.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Beyond the Dark Portal may as well be its own game. Tides of Darkness was basically like a tutorial (except the final levels) for the real thing, Beyond the Dark Portal is quite difficult. The enemy AI is much much better and actually regularly attacks you, it's very difficult to try to cheese any of the missions like in Tides of Darkness.
Attack-Move actually works (didn't in vanilla Wc2) but it's not recommended to use it when directly facing an enemy army or base, Beyond the Dark Portal requires some good micromanagement. Catapults/Ballista are a must, and enemy AI also loves to use them.
The 2 extra music tracks added are also really good.
10/10 expansion, 100% recommend

adding to this, and something that sadly doesn't work here is the ALT-Cheatcodes. If you wanted to know your current karma level you normally could use the ALT+213 Code to display your karma level (also current time & coordinates). It worked in the DOS-Version and also the Nuvie port (I just tested this), which was integrated into ScummVM. But somehow the ALT+213 (and other codes) don't work with ScummVM. A bug was filed in the forums but I doubt they can fix this, since the sourcecode came from a third party...

So as a workadround, what you can do is talk to IOLO (he has to be there, only works with him) and tell him:
SPAM
SPAM
SPAM
HUMBUG
then you can enter the cheat menue, and under "Edit Player" you can see your current karma level.

>>9654501
>The Sky Temple keys in 2 must be collected during the part of the game that you are told to do so, though, which is a big part of why 2 is weaker than 1.
There's a lot of things that make the Sky Temple Keys awkward to collect. All the keys are in the dark world, which sucks to explore even after getting the light suit. The dark world is much more disconnected than the light world so you spend a lot of time going in and out of portals.

The hint system for those is clever though. There's always a fallen Luminoth Keybearer in the light world counterpart to the dark world room where the key is hidden. It makes things a little tougher than the Artifact Temple dishing out all the hints for free, but it does make the world feel a bit more thought-out.

I get what he’s saying. Growing up without really using the internet I didn’t even know there was a console war. I played gameboy and NES and later on N64 and Gameboy Color and then GameCube and Gameboy Advance then Wii and DS and I just never ran out of things to play. I also wasn’t exactly rich so I hardly even came close to playing everything. Looking back at PS1 and 2s vast library I nor any of my friends, even my well off ones, had even half the games on those lists and knew of maybe only a couple of the larger ones like Metal Gear Solid they never got. Comparing something retroactively to its potential versus its actuality is a bit foolish. Games were expensive when you were a kid, piracy hardly golden. Hell, one of my friends wanted to borrow a game to pirate a copy for himself and he ended up destroying my disk, so I was very piracy averse after that experience for years. If you want to compare and argue about it now potential matters, but I don’t think it matters when you actually talk about the reality of the situation. I didn’t know anyone who had Symphony of the Night growing up, nowadays it’s my second favorite Castlevania behind Rondo of Blood and only slightly beating out Castlevania 3. But I didn’t play any of these games before I was an adult, what I played growing up was was Castlevania 1 and 2 on my dads NES, and I didn’t play any of the ones on my N64 because. Well I never actually saw any at GameStop or at a yard sale. I played rogue squadron and army men and Mario and Zelda. My pals with their PlayStations played Spyro and Crash and a lot of shitty shovelware I don’t really remember (like army men Kek)

And we all played on our game boys and gameboy advances because that’s just what you did. We’d get the game links and play advance wars together or trade our Pokémon. Nintendo put out and published some fantastic games on their handhelds.

It's no different than books. You could have a library in your home, or you could read them digitally from your phone, PC, or a dedicated device like a Kindle. And yet if you talk to people who enjoy reading, most tend to prefer reading on physical paper books and dream of having a library in their home. Games are no different. A collection is just a library of games, and although you could play them on your PC, phone, or a dedicated device like a Mister, real hardware is always a better experience for various reasons. And the reality is that most readers tend to use a combo of ebooks and physical books, and may gamers do the same. I have a large collection, but I also own a Retroid that I play on in bed sometimes. I've also got flash cartridges, a few mini consoles (Egret and Astro City), and have some emulators set up on my PC. So it's not as if I don't know what emulation is like. I also strictly emulated before I was able to start building a collection.

>>9653739
I’ll answer honestly since your post seems genuine. There are a number of reasons for me.

1. First off, I don’t pay hundreds of dollars for anything emulatable. The only game I’ve ever spent over $100 on is a PS3 game that emulates like absolute shit. I might buy Steel Battalion someday. I VERY rarely spend more than $30 even. I just have a lot of old stuff and hunt for deals, which is part of the fun for me

2. I like to browse. Buying physical games from my local shop keeps them in business so I can browse. This is actually helped by the prices of sought-after games shooting up—since those are unavailable I look over the shelf for something affordable that seems interesting. It pushes me to explore the console’s library more and I’ve found some of my favorite games of all time this way.

3. While I don’t intentionally buy games as an investment, the value of my collection is at this point far beyond what I paid for it. If I managed to sell my collection off at going rate (unlikely without years of work, I know) I could pay the down payment on a house at this point

4. If I have a big rom list I just don’t play anything. Having physical games in my shelf encourages me to play through them, and browsing what I have can remind me to start or finish a game. It creates a contact point that just doesn’t exist for a rom list.

5. Maybe the most schizo point, but I don’t trust that piracy will remain as easy at it is now forever. Just because the internet has stayed relatively unregulated for this long doesn’t mean it will be that way forever. I could write a manifesto about this but won’t here and now.

6. They’re neato and old hardware is cool. Fixing consoles and such taught me soldering skills that I’ve used to make money as a side hustle. I like being the guy with shelves of old games. My friends think its cool I have certain rare games. My ex gf was impressed that I had a certain rare game.

>>9653704
I think that for a long time on the internet collectors were the main source of information and discussion for these older games. Most gaming publications were just talking about the newest games, but collectors would keep the discussion on retro games alive. Collectors who would dedicate entire YouTube channels to retro games put out reviews and got more people interested in them, which boosted the popularity of collecting. Of course some people saw money to be made in this growing collector's market and that's where Metal Jesus and companies like Limited Run came in, making game collecting a scummy practice. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I moved about 6 years ago and boxed up all my games and consoles. Friend of mine took the box and traded it in at a gamestop behind my back. Needless to say we're not friends after I found out.
So I lost every single game and console I had owned since I was a kid. I can't really get anyone around me to understand that I have a lot of memories attached to some of those games.
Like you're stuck at your grandparents on a summer day because your mom has to work. You come in late in the evening and you're playing megaman on your grandparents giant, old, woody, RCA tv... sitting in the floor- you and your grandmother take turns between lives; seeing who can get the furthest past quickman lasers and heatman disappearing blocks. The lights outside slowly start to fade making the TV's glow even more impressive. That desperate urge to beat just one more level before it's time to eat.
Maybe I'm stupid, but not having those old carts and cd jewel cases sitting on my shelf makes me feel like something is just missing.
Lately I've been trying to hunt down and buy back just some of the games I used to own as a kid.
I have been searching high and low for just a handful of titles and some of them are ridiculous. Like I'm quite attached to the megaman series... but $1-2k for Tron Bonne? That's a game I have distinct memories paying $40 from mowing lawns for at a bestbuy. I can afford it no problem, but I just can't make myself do it. It feels irresponsible.
There's emu, but damnit I just want those few good things that were attached to memories back.
Sorry about the blogpost.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9654238
>Maybe I'm stupid, but not having those old carts and cd jewel cases sitting on my shelf makes me feel like something is just missing.
>Lately I've been trying to hunt down and buy back just some of the games I used to own as a kid.
I get it, I have the same feelings. My parents basically never bought games so if I wanted new games I was limited to birthday or Christmas if was lucky (emphasis on lucky, because there were several years where we didn't have Christmas at all), using whatever money I could round up through various means, or selling/trading what I already had. Unfortunately I lost most of my childhood game collection through selling and trading, and I don't really have much left. It's really sad actually. After I moved overseas I started my collection by picking up various games that I enjoyed as a kid. That was basically my only goal in the beginning, but after a while I started branching out and picking up games I've never played and ultimately that's where most of my collection has come from and has led to the most enjoyment. It's nice to be able to pull out a game I liked as a kid, and it's nice to be able to open the closet or look over at the shelf and see a collection that I would have been so jealous of when I was younger. Like you said, a lot of great memories get attached to this stuff and playing and bring you back to another time. A while back I was replaying Super Mario Sunshine and it reminded me of staying with my grandparents over the summer while my parents went to some Jesus camp thing.

Same with any art form. To make something good you need to develop your taste, and you do that by looking at what other people do and thinking about what you like or don't like about it.

posts.com:
I have finished ALT and it feels like I had a religious experience and not in a good sense of that word. A dozen of good maps tops, everything else was unbearable. In some levels you just don't know if you are looking at the wall, a door, a usable switch or a shootable switch. Other maps have platforming, tightrope walking in the seizure rooms, self-telefragging mazes, switches which seemingly do nothing but open some nook on the other side of a giant map, switches which can softlock some maps if you pressed them in the wrong time (map 13, fuck you).

Map 28 had you scaling the giant flesh tumor thing while avoiding cyberdemons' rockets so you can telefrag its eye (?) and in map 29 you scale the imploded remains of the same tumor so you can jump inside of it to go into the shadow zone of the crashed plane on the second level with ghost soldiers. I just finished F.E.A.R. It was alright.
Lots of people have said the AI is amazing, but I don't think so. Most of the callouts they would shout would be just plain wrong. The way they split into cover and tried to get behind the player was nothing groundbreaking either. No more complex than what elites did in Halo.
The shotgun was certainly fun to use, but little of that was in the gun itself - all the feedback is in how the enemies gib. Which is excellent to see in slow motion.
The rest of the roster of guns was plain, so I found myself using the shotgun most of the time, with the particle rife for tougher enemies.
Speaking of those - there wasn't nearly enough variety. Occasionally you'd get one of those heavily armored troopers. Or a bunch of drones together. But I think the combat would have been better served by mixing between things more often. Instead, it was just room after room of guys who are ready to be gibbed by the shotgun, posing no threat.

How do the sequels shape up compared to it?

The expansions have a pretty common bug where roughly halfway through Extraction Point the game will start crashing during loading the next level. But the new weapons are very satisfying to use at least.

I got around the issue by setting all graphics settings to the lowest and putting them back to full after successfully loading into the next level.

>>9653108
The lack in enemy / sequence variety is my biggest gripe, followed by the extremely slow jogging speed of the main character. One of the reasons why I love Half Life 1 so much is because it switched up it's setpieces and gameplay dynamics around a lot. One moment you're jumping over moving industrial machinery, then you're fighting grunts in literal trenches and machine gun positions, powering up railroad tracks so you can drive a cargo locomotive through the transportation system.

The base game FEAR also does a decent job of pacing the experience with NPC dialogue and meeting up with your team so even if the gameplay remains samey, there are some things to direct your interest other than just the shooting. Some parts of the expansions are better than others, like the parts of XP where you team up with a Delta Force guy are better than the sections where you go through long stretches alone without even the comlink guy talking to you. But each to their own.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9654139
- Starve your enemy.
- Acquire the control of the sky level. Air superiority is a must, so focus your attacks on the solar panels and the "hangar" strucutres. (You may built solar panels on the ground level)
- The artillery and the slow self-propelled turrets are useful in the underground level. Moreover, a good turtle strategy in the underground level is a good choice given that your main structures are immune from the mechas and the bombers.
- During the first minutes of your game, focus on the "cutting" weapons for your mechas in order to gain free components during the battles. (Axe is better)
- Learn the pattern of the concealment component.
- The Adversary AI isn't so refined, so you may use a good ol' quick getaway strategy with quick attacks and even quick retreats (focus on the lava pools.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9653016
It's not hard to make a Mame machine. But it's time consuming and the experience isn't the same as it was back in the 90s.

Arcade cabs usually had 1 game (unless it was a Neo Geo). And it played instantly when you dropped a quarter it in. No wait times or scrolling through tons of menus.

With Mame, people put thousands of games on their MAME machines. You walk up to a Mame machine and you can spend 10 minutes just scrolling through menus. Annoying and It really kills the vibe.

Plus you need to download roms, setup mame, fiddle with settings (which can take hours or days), test everything, tweak the controls to your likeing, and install a front-end (the pretty menu that you scroll through when choosing a game).

And worst of all, everytime Mame updates you need to re-download all your Roms again because the roms aren't compatible with the new version. I don't know why they haven't figured out a better way. If there's an error, then you deal with a lot Mame elitists who insult you and claim your an idiot. Even though Mame looks like it's still stuck in the era Windows 98. They havent updated their UI in decades.

When I want to play an arcade game, I don't want to use a computer. I want to instantly jump in the action. I don't want to deal with menus, error messages, or any other stuff that crops up.

I don't hate Mame and applaud the Mame team for preserving games. But I prefer original hardware when possible. It just feels better and less headache with setup.

Plus there are so many companies making hundreds of thousands if not millions by selling expensive custom arcade cabinets. Usually anywhere form $10K to 25K in price.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9653426
I've spoken with many old school arcade operators. I can offer some of their thoughts.

Some arcade machines kept track of how much they earned in the hidden operator test settings. Data would display on how much money/quarters that players put inside the machine on each difficulty. You could track the data.

If you made the difficulty too high, then casual players would give up and stop playing because it was too hard.

If you made it too easy, then the game wouldn't be seen as a challenge and your casual players would easily beat the on less quarters. Which means you earn less money.

The idea was to find the perfect middle ground. You could adjust default CPU difficulty on a scale from level 1 to level 10 in many games.

If your arcade was in an area with mostly casual players and children, then you kept the difficulty on moderate. You go easy on the kids to lure more quarters out of them. Give them just enough hope and they will give you more quarters.

For an arcade that had a lot of "pro players", operators kept the difficulty on high because they would be more of a challenge to pro players.

For some games like Fighting games, you could even adjust the default damage level.

For example, in the Philippines the the damage level was actually kept on 50% instead of the normal 100%. Kids didn't have a lot of money, so arcade owners would lower the damage so the players that visited often would be able to "feel" like they got their money's worth. Matches would be extra long due to lower damage. But this kept visitors coming to arcades. This happened in many countries in Asia, South America, and the Pacific Islands where kids had less money.

In America and Europe the damage was set to 100%

This led to an interesting scenario in "Marvel VS Capcom 2" when they were trying to host worldwide tournaments. Players argued on what should be the default damage level. Players spend their whole careers being used to a specific damage level.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9653543
>This led to an interesting scenario in "Marvel VS Capcom 2" when they were trying to host worldwide tournaments. Players argued on what should be the default damage level. Players spend their whole careers being used to a specific damage level.

Part 2 - Continued

There was some arguments and debates on what should be the default damage level for worldwide Marvel VS Capcom tournaments.

As an Asian/Filipino/South American player, if you spent hundreds of hours (or even a few thousand hours) learning to play your team on a lower damage setting then your whole play style revolves around that damage levels. You know how EXACTLY much damage your character can take but still survive. Or How to recover, counter, etc. It will be very difficult to adjust to higher damage.

For players in America and Europe, you've trained your muscle memory to be able to execute the combos you need to exactly kill the enemy team with damage level set to 100%. If the damage level is set to 50%, then suddenly your combos that would kill the enemy team will still leave them alive.

So there were debates and arguments between players about it. I think the American Players and European players won out because... Well they are richer and put more money into hosting the tournaments. So they decided the rules.

>>9653426
>Question for those who knew arcade operators personally:
>What was the general standard for setting the difficulty on arcade games?

It depended on the owner or manager. They decided how much money they could milk the players for. Could be medium. Could be hard.

>Did they even bother to change anything from factory settings?

Oh yeah. Everything was changed. Fun fact.

Lightgun games have an hidden option called "Time to Death." Basically it guarantees the player will be hit X amount of times no matter what.

Ever play House of the Dead and get hit by a zombie that you SWORE you shot its head off...but it hit you anyway before falling? That's the game setting I'm talking about. It guarantees a hit on the player. The operator can decide, no matter how skilled you are, that you will die by a certain point in the game no matter what you do. The only way is to put more quarters in.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9632031
There's nothing really "bad" about the Steam Deck. Its the best bang for your buck x86 handheld that there is, the trackpads are a great addition that I sometimes prefer using over the right analog stick for camera movement, and Valve updates Proton enough that games work more than they don't from my experience. Plus when you connect it to a Dock, there's tons of great upscaling options for 2D/3D games with SteamOS compared to Windows by default.
The only real cons are personal nitpicks, like how some games like RE4 don't make full use of the 16:10 display, displaying black bars on the top and bottom like its in widescreen. And while its large and is more comfortable to use than expected, its bulky enough that it isn't exactly "portable" like the Ayaneo Air if that makes any sense. Small hand-handed people may want to wait for their Air Plus model instead. And of course since this is running Linux, not all PC games like say Silent Hill 4 boot from my experience. Still want to stress that its not all unplayable and game compatibility is very good at this point and only growing, but still keep in mind.

>>9638357
Just bought some vitas. All on eBay. 2/3 were Japanese used: 1000 and 1100. Had to return the "excellent condition FW 3.18" for being the latest firmware and having severe burn-in from the hot charging port. The other JP one arrived perfectly, exactly as the seller and I personally discussed, and had the correct FW, no mura spots, no burn-in.
It does matter to get a 3.60 or lower firmware, people are lying when they say high FW can easily get CFW.
Ordered a US 1000 Vita to replace the returned 1100.
No interest in the 2000. The IPS is easier to take care of and internal memory card is convenient but offers no good sub pixel arrangement for crispness, no good blacks or contrasts, plus the 1000 OLED has good motion controls.
The OLED must be properly cared for though. You can't overcharge it or max the current to 2A over 5v constantly or you'll get burn-in. And you need a sleep timer or screensaver to prevent mura/splotches from developing, and set the brightness low most of the time for the same reason. It's actually worrying how bright it is at max. Halfway was still pretty bright in light and minimum is highly visible in the dark. So far this Vita looks pretty worth it. I love my PSP and it won't replace it for those games or the superior XMB clicky sounds but Vita is very good at its own thing.
If you're willing to message sellers directly and talk like a human being, you'll get a really sweet deal on an excellent condition Vita and then it's just a matter of taking care of it properly.
One more thing. The JP vitas have a different battery model in them than the US and EU versions. They're all the same true capacity BUT the JPN ones have the top & bottom 20%-iles locked off. For most people, this will help them not wreck their batteries in 3 years. For power users, it could be a concern if you need the freedom. Personally, I recommend not maxing/mining your charge if you get US/EU anyway and just get a large 30,000mAh battery bank you can carry instead.

>>9643123
I have only tried the Gamesir X2 USB Type-C (Bottom row, center column in your picture), but... The most Important things I can remember:

- Buttons and d-pad are on a whole new level compared to the RG351V I own,Provided that you like clicky tactile feedback.

- The short grips don't make it comfortable for twin stick gameplay. If you want to play FPS, get something bigger with grips that extend downwards, like the ones in the top corners. Or a smartphone clip for a ds4 or XB controller.

- It's not a great solution if you are going to use it on the go during short commutes, or if you have to change trains every 15-20 min. With no built-in battery and no off-button it keeps draining the phone's battery all the time, so you will want to disassemble it as soon as your train or bus gets to destination (and you need to be careful to not mess the usb port on the phone, that spring is extra strong).

Nothing of this is a problem if you will use it at home or get to sit on on public transport for 40 minutes without interruptions.

- Think carefully about which model you want, USB-C or Bluetooth. Many Android games don't support USB controllers (Apex Legends, but that one is dead now). I have the Xbox version and it's guaranteed to work with Gamepass, and Retroarch detects it ok, although it may give you some remapping headaches from time to time.

My personal experience:
1) Get the Gamesir X2 because another handheld is overkill and I already have a good quality phone that integer scales GBA perfectly and can do almost every system
2) I spend more time getting the phone in than playing (exagerated)
3) I have a close call while disassembling it (controller ends in the floor of the train while it brakes)
4) Another mishap happens when I can't grip it properly, folds itseld and one analog stick cap goes flying
5) I end getting an RG351v, the Gamesir ends at home. I keep saying I will use it on the couch, but... nope. In love with the 351, playing Pokémon Clover.

I screwed up my android settings beyond repair on my 353m so I reflashed the device with just arkos but after hearing what you said about improved performance I'd want reinstall it. Can I reflash both of those OS at the same time to basically get in as close to factory shipped as possible?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9647134
>screwed up my android settings beyond repair
Huh?

You can download both stock images here:
https://win.anbernic.com/download/261.html

The Android image is installed on the device's native storage not on an SD card like ArkOS. Download it above, it will come with a small tool to flash it onto an SD card. After that slot the card in your device's first port (TF1/INT.) and power it on, the update should start. Once it's finished you can remove the SD card and use it for something else.

If you ever run into problems of black screens or boot loops you'll probably have to open it up and disconnect the battery and re-flash the native Android OS after that.

I think so, but i did spend nearly 200$ by the time it was said and done. I used the funnyplaying laminated ITA kit, originally I had installed a no cut IPS kit but I didn't like how the display sat so far back from the glass. the ITA kit uses the bottom screen from a DS lite if i'm not mistaken and has the oem pixel grid effect. because it's a laminated kit it fits right up against the glass and there is no air gap.

the ita kit works on any GBA but on a 40 pin motherboard you need to remove a surface mount resistor. you no longer need to solder a power wire but it does have the option to solder button controls for brightness which I did, because I dont like the touch sensor control for that. with a laminated kit you need to use a shell specifically designed for it.

the install itself is not difficult. fitting the screen in so it sits flush can be a little finicky but once its in the rest just goes right together.

They are brands of Moorechip, a Chinese car electronics manufacturer. Their handhelds are made of leftover car parts. The Odin is basically a satnav with a controller.

I guess any corporate structure makes sense if you're Chinese enough.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9654398
Anbernic (Retrogame in that time) started as a reseller of powkiddy shit.
Then, one guy one day started making software for one of their products, the rs97, and wanted to make his own special handheld. So he reached out to Powkiddy, who had given him the bootloader for the rs97 so he could make better software for it, to help him in procuring the needed volume of chips (one guy alone can't even get in contact with chip manufacturers).
And thus, the Anbernic rg350 was born. Brainchild of Tony Jih, it was of much higher quality than the usual shit, so they created the Anbernic brand just to differentiate
Powkiddy = Anbernic = Retrogame = TrimUI
LDK = Moorechip = Retroid = Ayn
GKD is its own thing
Myoo = PocketGo

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9645658
For gen 1 either the Super GameBoy on the SNES or Pokemon Stadium with the Transfer PAK on the N64.

For gen 2, GBC, SGB or Transfer Pak. Gold and Silver look great on the SGB, but if you want to play Crystal on the TV, you'll need the Transfer Pak.

PS. The SGB has a hidden fast speed setting, similar to Doduo/Dodrio mode in Stadium, but you need a special SNES controller to access it.

PPS. Also worth noting, if you have a GBC, is that there's two interesting hacks for gen 1 games: one adds full color to them, the second adds better sprites from gen 2. You'll have a fully colored gen 1 experience that feels fresh, but you cannot use them hacks with a mono GB, SGB or Game Boy Tower in Stadium sadly.

Nowadays with PKHeX you can transfer a Pokemon from any emulated game to any other emulated game.
You can send your Pikachu from Yellow into Battle Revolution, your Red Gyarados from Crystal into X and Mega Evolve it, or even go the other way and catch a Gen I Pokemon in Scarlet or Violet and toss it back into a Game Boy game.
You can even export a team into Pokemon Showdown to battle with other people, or take one of your Showdown teams and play with it in game.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9646675
It can't go that far. PKHeX only emulates the official transfer methods, so it can't copy something from gen 2 to gen 3, and it can't transfer anything backwards. It can however copy gen 1-2 to gen 7, since Poke Transporter and Pokemon Bank supported the 3DS Virtual Console versions of RBY and GSC.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Short version:
>play Pokémon red or blue on an OG Game Boy or a Super Game Boy.

Full Pocket Monsters experience: a /vr/ guide
>know absolutely nothing about the franchise and first engage with it through newspapers articles about a cartoon show that caused epileptic attacks on children in Japan
>read video game magazine articles that talk about a social phenomenon in Japan, called "Pocket Monsters", see some small screenshots and design imagen and think it looks weird and foreign but cool
>Call up various local game stores and ask them if they sell this japanese Pocket Monsters Game, only for them to have no idea
>forget about it for a while and one day you casually watch the first episode of "Pokémon" on cable TV and then you keep watching all the first season, meanwhile:
>Get Red or Blue and play on a Game Boy, or a Super Game Boy. Better alternative: GB tower on Pokémon Stadium, and using Oak's Lab for item and pkmn management, much better than the menues on the GB games. But, for a first playthrough it's not mandatory.
>Once you beat the game and catch Mewtwo, watch Mewtwo Strikes Back kino
>Read the "electric tale of Pikachu" manga
>Get a friend or a way to get the Pokémon from the other version that you're missing. Play Stadium's gym leader castle to get starters, fossils, eeveees and hitmons.
>Also try to beat the different cups in the main Stadium game as a post-game challenge. Start training low level Pokémon and buff them/give TMs and customize them.
>Buy at least a pack of the TCG, even if you don't care playing it, it's good art on them.
>play Pokémon Pinball and the Game Boy TCGs if you want somen extra gen 1 experience on GB
>play Snap and Smash 64
>Start reading rumours about pikablu
>Get hype for "Pokémon 2"
>Download a japanese ROM of Pokémon Gold and play a bit of it on a poorly coded emulator
>Play the actual Gold or Silver cart on a GB Color or go full pokemaster and play on Stadium 2 using the GB Tower, then play the Stadium cups.

>>9650019
You can safely inject a custom save file into them and transfer your Pokemon, legit or not, into future games, so what's not to like? Emulation is good, no major glitches or issues. In Crystal they've added the GS Ball integration, so you can catch Celebi legally and it can appear as a shiny - if you were wondering why people started generating ("hacking") pink Celebis left and right some time ago, this is why. O and if you're playing the Japanese ROMs (doubt it?) of Gold and Silver, you'll have a purple Jynx sprite instead of black, same way it's been for years everywhere else. And... I think that's it? One way or another, they're killing the whole transfer thingy eventually, since they're shutting down 3DS e-shop by the end of March this year. For now, while you still can, just download the whole Pokemon Bank / Transporter app suite. You won't be able to download and set it up after March. For the VC releases, just download the ROM injects matching the region of your Nintendo account, you don't need to actually buy the games. I repeat, you do not need to buy the games in order to transfer Pokemon, you need the apps tied to your account and that's it.

>>9651910
I'm not a big fan of the 3rd gen in general, because as is the case with the human body - it consists mostly of water. All of that said, the engine is sound (think fastest Pokemon games overall, both in terms of movement and responsiveness), the spritework good - it's the newer entries that are kinda "meh". FireRed and LeafGreen aren't half bad though. They're not ground breaking, but do fix some bugs, introduce postgame content (not nearly as much as Emerald, but still), quality of life improvements and the artwork matches. "Shit" is kinda pushing it anon, IMHO. Plus you need to consider that before the VC releases of gen 1 and 2 games, if you wanted to see your Pokemon in newer entries - you had to start all over again with 3rd gen games. Mighty annoying and kinda fucked up, but it was what it was. If not for the existence of FR and LG, a lot of Kanto and Johto Pokemon would be stuck in limbo for years to come.

I've tried multiple times. It's barely progressed since ESRGAN. Any model that did present a huge improvement would be too large to train on consumer hardware anyway. https://paperswithcode.com/task/super-resolution/latest#code

The DKC trilogy isn't like Myst or PS1 games, the graphics are so compressed that they have more in common with pixel art, especially 2 and 3. There's not enough information for the AI to extrapolate.

>>9649915
>>9650028
>"why don't devs just make great games for my failed console???"
devs want big sales. no one wants to make a huge game for a platform that only 5% of the players own, and get only a fraction of sales you could have.
Sega CD launched in late 1992 in US for $300. That'd be over $600 in today's money, for just an add-on, not full console, that still had 2D graphics and hardly impressive FMVs that were literal AVGN material.
By comparison, same year, Genesis cost $99 (would be $200-something today). PS1 launched for $300, then quickly dropped the price to $200. that's literally a price of a full new console.
Needless to say, no one in their right mind would make games for an add-on (which already limits the player base), that costs 3x more than the console itself.
obviously, Japan could have helped. but Mega Drive wasn't very popular there, and not only that, it already had a huge competitor in PC-Engine, that had a CD-addon earlier and also made a pretty successful Turbo Duo.

The more I think about the whole Sega CD thing, and knowing the Genesis's weaknesses, the more I suspect they should've gone for a ground-up redesign and ASIC-ification.
Blob together the Genesis audio hardware with the Ricoh chip and add the extra sound memory.
Blob together the VDP with that custom Sega CD graphics chip, add the extra video RAM needed for full palette, 128K mode, extra effects etc.
Do a proper redesign of the audio/video filtering and amp logic (many Genesis revisions looked and sounded like ass because the amp/filter stage was borked).
Upclock the CPU to 12.5 MHz (same speed as the IRL Sega CD CPU).
Use a proper CD-ROM-grade drive.
Keep the cartridge slot for backcompat, have the console run in legacy mode when game logic is detected (it was doable, some of the later NEC consoles had the capability).
Ditch the internal save memory and make the save cartridge widely available.
Do a global Western launch early 1993 for $299.

>>9654241
IMO "mid-generation" consoles have always been a bad idea. they never sell all that much. today they became a bit more normal, since every console is basically a PC that can get upgraded, so it can play all the same games but with better graphics.
but before that, what happened? you get a console that needs its own dedicated software that won't work on the "base" console. a company that made it needs to spread talent/effort between Genesis and Sega CD. more than that, it needs to advertise the new platform, and make some really good games for it to help the launch (like Mario / Zelda / Sonic tier). and the console STILL naturally won't sell that much, as parents don't want to shell out several hundred $ every 2 years. the players will feel betrayed their old console gets less support. 3rd party devs will hardly want to develop for it, learning all the nuance of a new platform to get a fraction of sales. most notably, you hardly reach any new consumers. and 2-3 years later it still gets BTFO'd by new generation of "proper" consoles that get advertized to high heavens and bring in the actual next gen hardware. ESPECIALLY so when we talk 2D —> 3D transition.
it's just a vicious cycle. you deliberately spread effort between many consoles, instead of focusing on one.

Game is hoarded. Gets leaked. Hoarder (BakuDD) upset. Mirrored everywhere.

Vinesauce does a video playthrough. Gets /v/ attention, game is mirrored and tons of new videos are made. At this point, copyright troll reads on /v/ that the game has some devs who joined Nintendo later. So he files new takedowns as NINTENDO. He stops for a while. BakuDD crawls out of his basement and denies it's him.
Then he takes down everything except a couple of videos with the most views, biding his time until it all dies down. This time as Ukie, an ESA-type organisation but for the UK.

Discussion about that project fizzles out from /v/ .
In the discord server proper, some progress happens for adding subtitles in the game for the spoken lines and disabling the serial code. They don't have many Japanese translators either.

- BakuDD is in that server

It's a bit of an inbetween.

It's not bad, it's not average, it does its job well.
The thing that usually attracts people is the nature of the world itself, how adorable Cookie is that triggers in some people some kind of parental instinct to protect her from this dumb world she finds herself in, the music is really good and catchy and it's overall a charming experience.
I wouldn't call it a hidden gem, but it IS an interesting game.

https://boingboing.net/2019/11/18/horace-goes-copyright-striking.html

One example I can think of is Paul Andrews, who is part of a few companies like Retro Games Ltd and Subvert. Responsible for some re-releases of Lynx and microcomputer games. He seems to have made whatever pittance of a licensing agreement you need to with whatever legacy publisher notionally owns some relevant (but not very scrutinized) rights to some random old ZX Spectrum and C64 games which are not exactly hot commodities. You know, for the license to republish, maybe issue a "remake".

One of the more notable examples of this is that his company/companies "own" the rights to the Horace games on ZX Spectrum. A few years back he went on a tear, launching copyright takedowns for anything featuring Horace that he didn't like, including videos by some YouTuber whose content he felt "undermined Horace's family-friendly image." Further scrutiny suggests that the actual rights are murky at best far more limited than he suggests, meaning he likely doesn't even have the right to copyright strike anything. But hey, it's Horace, who's gonna put the money in to litigate against that?

>>9652542
From a modern point of view, it's basically unarguable that the Lucas games were "better designed". I like them better on average compared to the Sierra canon, but I have no problem acknowledging that the highly publicized and appreciated dead-end-less (and often death-less) design came with tradeoffs: the experience you'll get from how a game is designed is recursively part of its design, and knowing you can't possibly fuck up no matter what you do is a BIG crucial determinator, specially in story-driven experiences like graphic adventures.

At the end of the day, I remember more fondly the satisfaction and sense of achievement of playing through say Gabriel Knight or King's Quest VI than I got from LeChuck's Revenge or Day of the Tentacle (which I still fucking love).

Pre-teen kids; and only once they hit teenagehood would the parents let them go with the next generation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9653951
My parents didn't have a lot of money growing up, so I almost always had last gen's system up until a new generation's release. I only had an NES until 93, then an SNES until 97, and finally I got a PSX in 1999. Games for these systems were much cheaper this late into their cycle. This turned out to be a great thing later in life because I had quite a trove of games for older systems that I still connected up and played regularly, right up until my old CRT bit the dust.

The Wii was actually the first system I bought myself and got on release. Everything else was a Christmas present from my parents or in the case of the NES and Atari, a hand-me-down from family friends who had bought the latest consoles. Around 2002 was the year I started buying games on my own once I had a stream of income from a summer job, and during that time I started ordering old SNES and GB games from Ebay. I regret not filling out my collection more back then when everything was pretty cheap, not just because of the price, but because there's far more reproductions floating around.

While it is a little known fact that a good half of the enemies in Dragon Warrior 2 hand out more exp/gold than their counterparts in Dragon Quest 2, what nobody knowns (and which isn't documented yet) is that the stats of all enemies were also rebalanced for the western version.

Every enemy in Dragon Warrior 2 is easier. Whether that is attack, def or agility, values, and I think in some cases even HP and probability to use this or that move (I'd have to check back to make sure of that). In most cases there are subtle changes to most values.

So when you see people who have played Dragon *Warrior* 2 and hear them cry about
>waaah this game is too hard! I mean the end game is hard how does that make sense??!! Look even the devs said it was too hard!
They have absolutely no right to use the dev stuff as an excuse because they were already playing a version in which the difficulty had been adressed to begin with.

Dilate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9633787
While it is a technical possibility to get ambushed and OHKO'd from a death spell in the late game, it is very unlikely to happen when you reached the level gap. The higher your level, the less likely you will be to get ambushed, and the less likely death spells will be likely to hit.

>>9633749
>specially the sun one which is found on a specific tile on a southeastern shrine.

There is an NPC that tells you exactly where the shard is. That and you get the flute to help you locate the shards.That and the shrine is likely to be a place you visit when you use the warps.

As long as you pay attention and take notes when NPCs say things, you shouldn't have too much trouble.
Personally I love this stuff in the game, these adventure game mechanics are exactly what makes the game feel organic and alive, rather than having a game-y world with a tired "area is composed of one town, one dungeon, complete that and you're allowed to go the next area and repeat" routine.
In DQ2 towns work as hubs you come back to
in between several quests, and their inhabitants often provide clues that will be needed for things much later on; that and there is often a reason to come back to X or Y location later on. This makes the world feel alive and enhances the feel of adventure, something many other RPGs (DQ sequels included) fail at because they want to cater to the part of the audiance that just wanted to be hand holded through an adventure game.

The source is me checking the game code coupled with existing dissassembly and documentation to help (though I don't trust the dissassembly too much because external docs that come with it talk about things which aren't in the game at all, must be a romhack or something)

Example, Big Slug data in the Japanese version
08 00 03 01 04 0B 06 00 07 00 00 00 00 00

Big Slug data in the US version
08 00 03 02 03 09 06 00 07 00 00 00 00 00

So on top of the exp given being changed from 01 to 02 (already a known thing easily checked by playing or checking guides), the attack value was changed from 0B to 09, losing 2 points.

Pretty much every enemy has changes like that, some more substantial than that too.

I'll document it all one of these days, but it takes time; and I intend to check up on other things too like probability for enemies to use this or that spell or to drop items etc

>>9643352
>know more than the devs

The "we didn't have time to properly test and balance the game" excuse was from a Japanese interview, thus talking about the Japanese version. One should also take into account that they spent one month and a half (november/december 1986) doing nothing but debugging and balancing the game. That's a lot of time. The game was delayed for that purpose specifically.
The fact is, making RPGs hard and require grinding was a norm then, which as a whole gradually decreased with time (and the US version is from 1990, thus the adjustements)

posts.com:
I just checked the code (again, US NES version) and whenever Gold Batboons attempts to do Sacrifice, it checks its remaining HP and compares it to value 1C, which equals 28 in decimal; and proceeds to fuck off if the value is higher.
28 being 25% of 112, the Gold Batboon's max HP value when it spawns (as stated HP may vary), so it's not really 25% of its health, but 25% of its max possible health.

One interesting thing I'm not sure I fully understand however is that if you have 2 Gold Batboons, it checks both enemies HP values. I *think* what happens is that Gold Batboon A may very well be the one to use Sacrifice if Gold Batboon B is the one with low HP; not that the player will know because he will be kill.

This is without a doubt the worst Sega of America game on the saturn. Sega of America had some good games on genesis but they were mostly shit on saturn.

Three Dirty Dwarves is a decent beat’em up. Especially with multiplayer.

Mr Bones is a variety collection of minigames that is about the most creative thing SOA did on Saturn. Its unique and fun, but not really a killer app. Just 20 decent minigames and a stupid ice level. Its probably SOA’s best Saturn game.

Manx TT Super bike was farmed out. Its great but only has 2 courses.

Then there’s Sky Target; a rail shooter that is just terrible compared to the excellent Panzer Dragoons or Afterburner (the game it wanted to be) on previous consoles.

Theres SCUD an accurately named shitty, repetitive run’n gun with light gun options. Its maybe fun for a few minutes but thats all I get from it.

Bug! and Bug! 2 come close to Congo in terms of shittyness. Again boring repetitive 2d platformers with some supposedly fancy graphics for the day. The graphics are no longer impressive if they ever were. I could get over the graphics and maybe they were cool back then but the gameplay is atrocious, boring and has no high points. Definition of a grueling slog. Plenty of Sega’s 2d Genesis, Saturn or Master System platformers are way better.

That leaves a few sports games I haven’t played.

Congo is without a doubt an order of magnitutde worse than every game I’ve mentioned. Bad performance, enemies appering almost on top of you, unlimited enemies that are all the same, bad quality graphics, unclear goals, small playing areas and overall jankiness. This may be the absolute worst game the Saturn has to offer. Poor sound and music, janky motion, and underlying it all a very badly designed game both in level design and overall. Powerslave, Duke, Quake, Alien trilogy, Hexen and even Saturn Doom are vastly superior, bot to mention the excellent mecha FPS games on the system.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Just Breed
Tactical RPG which unlike Fire Emblem leans more towards the RPG elements. You can explore towns, talk to people, shop, etc However the combat is tactical grid based. Unlike in FE or Famicom Wars, an attacked unit will not retaliate on the turn it is attacked. Gameplay is based around generals, the player has up to 4 teams each with 1 general and 5 units composed of fighters, archers, and mages (offensive or defensive). Units belonging to a general can not leave the current screen the general is on, so it is him that gives the overall movement of the team.
Nice graphics and musics. Difficulty a bit on the easy side. You can replay battles to grind for exp/gold and the game seems to expect you to do that at least if you want to buy an acceptable amount of gear in shops.
What's impressive about it is the amount of characters the game can have on the screen at once. The game uses background graphics for the characters, unless it is currently the unit in play in which case it will turn into sprites for the time being. Smart.
On the bad side, the game rarely goes beyond the battle->town->repeat routine. Most of the game has the same two musics on loop (battle and town), despite the musics being of quality. A waste on that side as well as with graphics, a mangaka was hired for monster designs but you only see enemy designs in small windows when you select them (there are no battle anims).
Also, the game insists on using the same few palettes for the majority of towns, even when it really doesn't fit. All of this makes the game very monotonous.

All in all the game feels like a wasted opportunity: published by Enix, allegedly took 3 years to dev and hired famous mangaka and composer, and all that for what? A tired town->battle routine, "tactical" gameplay that can easily boil down to "just grind lol", enemy design in small windows that you don't get to see, and the same two musics looping for most of the game.
It IS a good game, but it should have been more.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Moryo Senki Madara

By Konami, based on a Manga license unknown to me, but the double page ad for this game was all over Japanese magasines at the time of release. The story failed to catch my interest and felt like you had to know the original work to fully enjoy it.
Great soundtrack using the same soundchip as Castlevania 3, there are even several world map themes.
Good graphics with Konami's trademark huge characters, lot's of great looking graphical cutscenes.
Combat is turned based, but top down and semi automatic: you can pause the action at any time to input commands for the next turn(s). Characters/enemies move around the screen to attack. For a semi-automatic system, there is a surprising amount of tactic involved and battles often get exciting.
Sprites are small during combat, but you get a graphical view of the enemies Dragon Quest style before battles which I appreciated a lot (they knew the impact of such graphics on the player, vs their small sprites during combat which rarely looked menacing)
Until the late game and revive item/spell, you do NOT want any character to die. You have to go through hell to get them back AND they will lose all their gear and items.
The game can get really brutal in difficulty, at least until you figure out a couple of tricks (one involves grinding the physical and magical attack power stats easily and quickly, the other involves protective spells).
Seasons change with time on the overworld map, a couple of events are tied to it.
The game is fairly long too. Exploration and dungeons get more complicated and interesting as the game goes on, perhaps a bit too many floor pits and teleporters in the late game dungeons.
In some ways, it felt like this game paved the way for Lagrange Point.
[cont]
